com.gl.vn.me.ko.pies.base.constant

Class Message

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.gl.vn.me.ko.pies.base.constant.Message

  • public final class Message
extends Object
    Provides Application's internal string resources that allow to specify common messages in a generic way. Some string values contain %s macroses that SHOULD be substituted by using format(String, Object...) method or Preconditions methods.

    Examples of usage: 

    
 //the message is "The second argument arg2 is illegal"
 Preconditions.checkArgument(arg2 >= 0, Message.ARGUMENT_ILLEGAL, "second", "arg2");

 //the message is "The argument arg is null"
 Preconditions.checkNotNull(arg, Message.ARGUMENT_NULL_SINGLE, "arg");

    • Field Detail

      • INSTANTIATION_NOT_SUPPORTED

        public static final String INSTANTIATION_NOT_SUPPORTED
        Specifies impossibility of constructor call. Example of usage: 
        
 throw new UnsupportedOperationException(Message.INSTANTIATION_NOT_SUPPORTED);
        Value of this constant is "The class is not designed to be instantiated" .
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • OPERATION_NOT_SUPPORTED

        public static final String OPERATION_NOT_SUPPORTED
        Specifies impossibility of method invocation. Example of usage: 
        
 throw new UnsupportedOperationException(Message.OPERATION_NOT_SUPPORTED);
        Value of this constant is "The method is not supported" .
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • ARGUMENT_NULL

        public static final String ARGUMENT_NULL
        Specifies that an argument of a method is null. Example of usage: 
        
 Preconditions.checkNotNull(arg, Message.ARGUMENT_NULL, "first", "arg");
        Value of this constant is "The %s argument %s is null" .
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • ARGUMENT_NULL_SINGLE

        public static final String ARGUMENT_NULL_SINGLE
        Specifies that the only argument of a method is null. Example of usage: 
        
 Preconditions.checkNotNull(arg, Message.ARGUMENT_NULL_SINGLE, "arg");
        Value of this constant is "The argument %s is null" .
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • ARGUMENT_ILLEGAL

        public static final String ARGUMENT_ILLEGAL
        Specifies that an argument of a method is illegal. Example of usage: 
        
 Preconditions.checkArgument(arg > 0 && arg < 3, Message.ARGUMENT_ILLEGAL, arg, "first", "arg",
 		"Expected value must be greater than 0 and lower than 3");
        Value of this constant is "Value %s of the %s argument %s is illegal. %s" .
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • ARGUMENT_ILLEGAL_SINGLE

        public static final String ARGUMENT_ILLEGAL_SINGLE
        Specifies that the only argument of a method is illegal. Example of usage: 
        
 Preconditions.checkArgument(size > 2, Message.ARGUMENT_ILLEGAL, size, "size",
 		"Expected set must contain at least two elements");
        Value of this constant is "Value %s of the argument %s is illegal. %s" .
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • INSTANTIATION_FAILED

        public static final String INSTANTIATION_FAILED
        Specifies that instantiation of a class via the Class.newInstance() method failed. Example of usage: 
        
 throw new ApplicationException(Message.format(Message.INSTANTIATION_FAILED, klass.toString()));
        Value of this constant is "Failed to instantiate class %s" .
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • INSTANTIATION_FAILED_CTOR

        public static final String INSTANTIATION_FAILED_CTOR
        Specifies that instantiation of a class via the Constructor.newInstance(Object...) method failed. Example of usage: 
        
 throw new ApplicationException(Message.format(Message.INSTANTIATION_FAILED_CTOR, ctor.toString()));
        Value of this constant is "Failed to instantiate class via constructor %s" .
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • CAN_NEVER_HAPPEN

        public static final String CAN_NEVER_HAPPEN
        Specifies message for exceptional situation that "can never happen". E.g. execution of a default block in a switch statement that tests for each value of some enum. It's possible that a new value was added to the enum without updating the switch statement, but this is very unlikely and, even if it will happen, there will be no need in any runtime information for investigation of the problem.

        Example of usage: 

        
 throw new ApplicationError(Message.CAN_NEVER_HAPPEN);
        Value of this constant is "Surprise Motherfucker! You see a error that could never happen. There are two possibilities: the End of the World is coming, or something is very wrong with the Application".
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • SWALLOWED

        public static final String SWALLOWED
        Specifies message for situation when one had to swallow a Throwable.

        Example of usage: 

        
 LOGGER.error(Message.SWALLOWED, swallowedException);
        Value of this constant is "This exception was swallowed and logged only".
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • GUICE_POTENTIALLY_SWALLOWED

        public static final String GUICE_POTENTIALLY_SWALLOWED
        Specifies message that MAY be used to describe Throwable logged from implementation of AbstractModule. The thing is that sometimes (I can't figure out strict test case) Guice swallows exceptions that were thrown from methods marked with Provides and exits JVM. So it's RECOMMENDED to catch any possible RuntimeException and log it before rethrowing.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • format

        public static final String format(String format,
                                  Object... args)
        This method SHOULD be used to format constants provided by the Message class as well as any other strings that isn't user-specific. The method calls String.format(Locale, String, Object...) by specifying Constant.LOCALE as Locale and therefore guarantees that the formatted string will not depends on the system locale. If your format doesn't contain any locale-specific format specifiers then you MAY use String.format(String, Object...) directly (e.g. this is useful when using Preconditions).
        Parameters:
        format - A format string as specified in String.format(Locale, String, Object...).
        args - Arguments referenced by the format specifiers in the format string. See String.format(Locale, String, Object...) for details.
        Returns:
        A formatted string.
